title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which imperial goals of the French and of the British fostered differences in their relationships with American Indians in the period from 1607 to 1754. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include:

· The British and the French used their relationships with American Indians to gain access to valuable trade goods and to establish defensive alliances against each other’s influence.

· The relationships between American Indians and Europeans hinged mostly on whether the Europeans focused on trade (the French) or on settlement (the British) in the Americas.

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to British and French relationships with American Indians.

The response describes a broader historical context relevant to British and French relationships with American Indians.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context include the following, provided the essay clearly connects them to the prompt:

· Competition increased between European powers over access to resources to fulfill demand at home, especially in the fur trade.

· Britain and France competed with each other to establish alliances with American Indians.

· There were large populations of British settlers compared with relatively low French populations.

· British settlement focused mainly along the Atlantic coast.

· French settlers and traders primarily lived in the Great Lakes and Mississippi River regions.

title: PART C1:EVIDENCE – PROVIDES EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml:
To earn one point, the response must identify at least two specific pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not provide at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to British and French relationships with American Indians in the period from 1607 to 1754.

The response provides at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to British and French relationships with American Indians in the period from 1607 to 1754.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of evidence used might include:

· Albany Congress

· Battle of Fort Necessity

· Beaver Wars

· Fur trade

· Intermarriage between American Indians and French settlers

· Iroquois Confederacy

· Hudson’s Bay Company

· Joint-stock companies

· King George’s War (War of Jenkins’ Ear)

· King William’s War

· Metacom’s Rebellion (King Philip’s War)

· Métis people

· Missionary activity

· Praying towns

· Queen Anne’s War

· Spread of contagious diseases to American Indians

· Trans-Atlantic trade

title: PART C2: EVIDENCE – USES EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT AN ARGUMENT
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must use at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not support an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.
